abstract: <jats:p>Over the past decade, molecular approaches to species delimitation have seen rapid development. However, species delimitation based on a single locus, for example, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> barcodes, can lead to inaccurate results in cases of recent speciation and incomplete lineage sorting. Here, we compare the performance of Automatic Barcode Gap Discovery (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">ABGD</jats:styled-content>), Bayesian Poisson tree processes (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">PTP</jats:styled-content>), networks, generalized mixed Yule coalescent (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GMYC</jats:styled-content>) and Bayesian phylogenetics and phylogeography (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BPP</jats:styled-content>) models to delineate cryptic species previously detected by <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> barcodes within <jats:italic>Tanytarsus</jats:italic> (Diptera: Chironomidae) non‐biting midges. We compare the results from analyses of one mitochondrial (cytochrome <jats:italic>c</jats:italic> oxidase subunit I [<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">COI</jats:styled-content>]) and three nuclear (alanyl‐tRNA synthetase 1 [AATS1], carbamoyl phosphate synthetase 1 [CAD1] and 6‐phosphogluconate dehydrogenase [PGD]) protein‐coding genes. Our results show that species delimitation based on multiple nuclear <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> markers is largely concordant with morphological variation and delimitations using a single locus, for example, the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">COI</jats:styled-content> barcode. However, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">ABGD</jats:styled-content>,<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"> GMYC</jats:styled-content>,<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"> PTP</jats:styled-content> and network models led to conflicting results based on a single locus and delineate species differently than morphology. Results from <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BPP</jats:styled-content> analyses on multiple loci correspond best with current morphological species concept. In total, 10 lineages of the <jats:italic>Tanytarsus curticornis</jats:italic> species complex were uncovered. Excluding a Norwegian population of <jats:italic>Tanytarsus brundini</jats:italic> which might have undergone recent hybridization, this suggests six hitherto unrecognized species new to science. Five distinct species are well supported in the <jats:italic>Tanytarsus heusdensis</jats:italic> species complex, including two species new to science.</jats:p>
title: Exploring species boundaries with multiple genetic loci using empirical data from non‐biting midges
